Parker5, Aleix Prat4, 6, 7and Benjamin Haibe-Kains1, 2, * 1Bioinformatics and Computational Laboratory, Princess Margaret Cancer Centre,  University Health Network and2Department of Medical Biophysics, University of Toronto,  Toronto,  ON,  Canada, 3UCD School of Biomolecular and Biomedical Science, Conway Institute,  University College Dublin,  Dublin,  UK, 4Translational Genomics and Targeted Therapeutics in Solid Tumors, August Pi i Sunyer Biomedical Research Institute (IDIBAPS),  08036 Barcelona,  Spain, 5Lineberger Comprehensive Cancer Center,  University of North Carolina,  Chapel Hill,  NC 27599, USA, 6Translational Genomics Group,  Vall dHebron Institute of Oncology (VHIO),  08035 Barcelona, Spain and 7Department of Medical Oncology,  Hospital Cl  nic of Barcelona,  08036 Barcelona, Spain *To whom correspondence should be addressed., Associate Editor John Hancock Received on August 6,  2015,  revised on November 4,  2015, accepted on November 19,  2015 Abstract Summary, Breast cancer is one of the most frequent can cers among women., Extensive studies into the molecular heterogeneity of breast cancer have p roduced a plethora of molecular subtype classifica- tion and prognosis prediction algorithms, as well as numerous gene expression signatures., However reimplementation of these algorithms is a tedious b ut important task to enable comparison of existing signatures and classification models between eac h other and with new models., Here we present the genefu R/Bioconductor package, a multi-tiered compendium of bioinformatics algorithms and gene signatures for molecular subtyping and prognostication in breast cancer., Availability and implementation: The genefu package is available from Bioconductor. http://www. bioconductor.org/packages/devel/bioc/html/genefu.html. Source code is also available on Github https://github.com/bhklab/genefu. Contact bhaibeka@uhnresearch.ca Supplementary information, Supplementary data are available at Bioinformatics online., 1 Introduction Breast cancer is a devastating dise ase whose management is compli- cated by its high molecular heterogen eity., Breast cancer is categorized into at least four clinically relevant molecular subtypes that reflectupon expression levels of specific genes ( Koboldt et al., , 2012 ). These are Her2-enriched (also called HER2 ) Triple-negative breast cancers (ER /C0/HER2 /C0/PR/C0, similar to basal-like) and Luminal-like which are mainly ER /HER2 /C0that could be further discriminated into luminal A and B based on their low and high proliferativephenotype, respectively., These classifications have showed that breast cancer is not a single disease but is rather highly heterogeneous., Breastcancer subtypes exhibit distinct trans criptomic patterns that are associ- ated with outcome which emphasizes the relevance of these subtypesfor basic and translational research ( Sotiriou and Pusztai, 2009 )., Among various molecular techniques gene expression profiling in particular has increasingly been used to refine breast cancer stratifica-tion, and to assess prognosis and response to therapy ( Pratet al.,  2012 )., Studies to identify gene expression patterns of clinical potential have VCThe Author 2015. Subtype- specific prognoses however are also largely dependent on the properidentification of the major biological subtypes., The parallel develop-ment of breast cancer subtyping methods has also produced a signifi-cant number of classification algorithms, with diverse taxonomies., The large body of literature on the molecular complexity of breast cancer has introduced a burden of computational complexity for re-searchers., The advent of high-throughput genomics and next-gener-ation sequencing promises unprecedented views into the majorbiological breast cancer subtypes ( Schnitt, 2010 )., However there is a dire need for an accessible, computat ional platform that can easily sus- tain the growing variety of breast can cer classification and prognostic algorithms., This will facilitate both meta-analyses of breast cancer dataas well as cross comparison of diffe rent computational methods., Here we have developed the genefu package, a multi-leveled compendium that provides bioinformatics implem entations of classification algo- rithms to identify molecular subtypes, as well as prognostic predictorsalong with their published gene signatures ( Table 1 , Supplementary Fig., S1 ). Notably we have incorporated the most recently developed molecular subtyping algorithms in the field, including the IntClust (Curtis et al.,  2012 ), the IHC4 prognostic scoring algorithm ( Dowsett et al.,  2013 ), the Absolute Intrinsic Molecular Subypting (AIMS) algo- rithm ( Paquet and Hallett,  2015 ), as well as the classification algorithm for prediction of claudin-low breast cancer samples ( Pratet al., 2010 )., The package also includes other functions to facilitate quick manipula-tion of gene expression datasets, including gene selection and probe-gene mapping across microarray platforms., 2 Molecular subtyping We have implemented nine molecular subtyping algorithms withingenefu which facilitates the identification of molecular subtypes as well as assessment of stratified patient data., We compare here themolecular subtype predictions across five public datasets using thePAM50 and SCMOD2 algorithms., Both PAM50 and SCMOD2 pre- dict patients that belong to the Basal-like and Her2-enriched sub-types, as well as distinguish between the Luminal A (LumA) andLuminal B (LumB) subtypes., PAM50 additionally identifies nor-mal-like patients. Overall, there is a concordance of /C2485% between both predictors ( Supplementary Data S1 ). Despite the lack of com- plete concordance between the two algorithms patient survivalacross subtypes is virtually identical between the two subtypingschemes ( Fig., 1 A). Notably survival is the highest for LumA pa- tients,  while patients LumB, Her2-enriched and Basal-like tumorsdisplay the poorest survival., This indicates that different molecularsubtyping algorithms are consistent and yield similar prognosticvalue across breast cancer subtypes., 3 Prognostication of breast cancer Our implementation of numerous prognostic predictors as part ofgenefu facilitates meta-analysis of prognostic signatures across sev- eral breast cancer datasets., We previously demonstrated that themajority of prognostic signatures show similar performance despitelimited genetic overlaps between them ( Desmedt et al., , 2008 ; Wirapati et al. , 2008 ). We showed that many of published gene sig- natures were affected by the presence of proliferation-related genes, rendering the signature informative for prognosis of ER /HER2 /C0 patients, but less informative for basal-like and HER2-enriched pa-tients., To improve prognostication for these subtypes we imple-mented a new risk prediction model, called GENIUS, which uses afuzzy computational approach combining risk prediction modelsspecific to each molecular subtype ( Haibe-Kains et al., , 2010 ). We have subsequently demonstrated that Gaussian-based clusteringbased on gene sets specifically correlated with the ER, HER2 andAURKA genes can robustly identify breast cancer molecular sub-types ( Haibe-Kains et al., 2012 )., In this case study we used genefu to conduct a meta-analysis of 12 risk predictors across 71 3 node-negative, untreate d breast cancer patients (Supplementary Data S1 )., For comparison three of our predictors were based on using just one of three key breast cancer genes (representedhere as AURKA, ESR1 and ERBB2)., We calculated the risk score per-formance of each predictor measured by the concordance index, acrossthe five breast cancer datasets ( Supplementary Fig., S2 ). Notably using a single prolifer ation gene (AURKA) produces a similar performance to the majority of other predictors., 4 Application across data platforms Many of the molecular subtyping algorithms and gene expression sig-natures implemented within genefu have originally been derived from microarray gene expression data., This raises an important question asto whether such methods can be used on data generated on RNAsequencing platforms., We have previously compared the agreementbetween microarray and RNAs sequencing platforms on several prog-nostic signatures and classifiers from genefu (Fumagalli et al., 2 0 1 4 )., This analysis was conducted on six molecular subtyping algorithms(SCMOD1 SCMO2,  SCMGENE,  SSP2003, SSP2006 and PAM50)and several prognostic-driven signatures including GENE70,  GGI,  RORS, ENDOPREDICT, among other gene expression signatures.We have demonstrated that the clinically relevant single genes andgene expression signatures originally defined by microarray technol-ogy can be used to reliably evaluate RNA sequencing data., The codefor this analysis is additionally available on github at https://github.com/bhklab/DNA11161. 5 Conclusions Thegenefu package provides a unified framework for integration of molecular subtype and survival analysis of breast cancer., We havedemonstrated how the package can be utilized to perform bothmeta-analyses across datasets and across algorithms, to facilitateintegrated analysis of breast cancer gene expression profiles., Acknowledgements The authors would like to thank Dr. Michael Hallet for sharing his feedback and experiences regarding implementation of some of the breast cancer mo-lecular subtyping schemes., Funding CIBC-Brain Canada Brain Cancer Research Training Award to DMAG. qa_pairs.question: What is the main objective of the research in this paper?
qa_pairs.answer: The main objective of the research presented in the paper is to develop the genefu R/Bioconductor package, which serves as a comprehensive computational tool for the analysis of gene expression-based signatures in breast cancer. This package aims to facilitate the identification of molecular subtypes and prognostic predictors, enabling researchers to compare existing gene expression signatures and classification models effectively. By providing a unified framework for integrating various molecular subtype classification algorithms and prognostic models, genefu addresses the computational complexity associated with the diverse and evolving landscape of breast cancer research.

qa_pairs.question: Can you summarize the abstract of the paper?
qa_pairs.answer: The abstract of the paper discusses the development of the genefu R/Bioconductor package, which provides a comprehensive set of bioinformatics tools for analyzing gene expression data related to breast cancer. It highlights the challenges posed by the molecular heterogeneity of breast cancer, which has led to numerous classification and prognostic algorithms. The genefu package aims to facilitate the comparison of existing gene expression signatures and classification models, making it easier for researchers to implement and analyze these algorithms. The package includes various molecular subtyping methods and prognostic predictors, and it is available for use on Bioconductor and GitHub.

qa_pairs.question: What are the softwares and computational tools that were used in this paper?
qa_pairs.answer:
The software and computational tools used in the paper are primarily centered around the **genefu** package, which is an R/Bioconductor package designed for the computation of gene expression-based signatures in breast cancer. The package includes various bioinformatics algorithms and gene signatures for molecular subtyping and prognostication in breast cancer.

Additionally, the paper mentions the following specific algorithms and tools implemented within the genefu package:

1. **IntClust** - A molecular subtyping algorithm.
2. **IHC4** - A prognostic scoring algorithm.
3. **Absolute Intrinsic Molecular Subtyping (AIMS)** - Another molecular subtyping algorithm.
4. **PAM50** - A well-known molecular classification algorithm.
5. **SCMOD1, SCMOD2, SCMODGENE** - Subtype clustering models.
6. **Single Sample Predictors (SSP2003, SSP2006)** - Predictors for molecular subtypes.
7. **GENIUS** - A risk prediction model that uses a fuzzy computational approach.

The genefu package is available from Bioconductor (http://www.bioconductor.org/packages/devel/bioc/html/genefu.html) and the source code can also be accessed on GitHub (https://github.com/bhklab/genefu). The paper also references the use of RNA sequencing data and microarray platforms for gene expression profiling, indicating a broader computational context for the analysis.

qa_pairs.question: Describe the methodology used in the paper.
qa_pairs.answer:
The methodology used in the paper revolves around the development and implementation of the genefu R/Bioconductor package, which serves as a comprehensive tool for the computation of gene expression-based signatures in breast cancer. Here are the key components of the methodology:

1. **Package Development**: The genefu package was created as a multi-tiered compendium that integrates various bioinformatics algorithms and gene signatures aimed at molecular subtyping and prognostication in breast cancer. This package is designed to facilitate the comparison of existing signatures and classification models.

2. **Molecular Subtyping Algorithms**: The authors implemented nine molecular subtyping algorithms within the genefu package. These algorithms help identify molecular subtypes of breast cancer and assess stratified patient data. Notable algorithms included are PAM50 and SCMOD2, which were compared across five public datasets to evaluate their concordance in predicting subtypes such as Basal-like, Her2-enriched, Luminal A, and Luminal B.

3. **Prognostic Predictors**: The methodology includes the implementation of numerous prognostic predictors that allow for meta-analysis across various breast cancer datasets. The authors highlighted the development of a new risk prediction model called GENIUS, which employs a fuzzy computational approach to combine risk prediction models specific to each molecular subtype.

4. **Data Analysis**: The authors conducted a meta-analysis of 12 risk predictors across 713 node-negative, untreated breast cancer patients. They calculated the performance of each predictor using the concordance index, which estimates the probability that a randomly selected patient pair will have their outcomes ordered correctly based on their risk scores.

5. **Cross-Platform Application**: The paper discusses the applicability of the molecular subtyping algorithms and gene expression signatures derived from microarray data to RNA sequencing data. The authors previously compared the agreement between these two platforms and demonstrated that clinically relevant gene expression signatures could be reliably evaluated across both data types.

6. **Statistical Methods**: The methodology involved using a random-effects model to combine dataset-specific performance estimates into an overall performance estimate for each risk prediction model.

Overall, the methodology emphasizes the integration of various computational tools and statistical analyses to enhance the understanding and prognostication of breast cancer through gene expression profiling.

qa_pairs.question: What are the key findings of the paper?
qa_pairs.answer:
The key findings of the paper "Genefu: an R/Bioconductor package for computation of gene expression-based signatures in breast cancer" are as follows:

1. **Development of Genefu Package**: The authors introduced the genefu R/Bioconductor package, which serves as a comprehensive tool for the computation of gene expression-based signatures for molecular subtyping and prognostication in breast cancer. This package integrates various bioinformatics algorithms and gene signatures, facilitating the comparison of existing models and the development of new ones.

2. **Molecular Heterogeneity of Breast Cancer**: The paper emphasizes the high molecular heterogeneity of breast cancer, categorizing it into at least four clinically relevant subtypes (Her2-enriched, Triple-negative, Luminal A, and Luminal B). These subtypes exhibit distinct gene expression patterns associated with patient outcomes.

3. **Implementation of Subtyping Algorithms**: The genefu package includes nine molecular subtyping algorithms, allowing for the identification of molecular subtypes and assessment of stratified patient data. The concordance between different algorithms (e.g., PAM50 and SCMOD2) was found to be significant, with similar prognostic values across breast cancer subtypes.

4. **Prognostic Predictors**: The package facilitates meta-analysis of prognostic signatures across multiple datasets. The authors demonstrated that many prognostic signatures perform similarly despite limited genetic overlap, and introduced a new risk prediction model called GENIUS, which combines risk prediction models specific to each molecular subtype.

5. **Application to RNA Sequencing Data**: The study confirmed that gene expression signatures derived from microarray data can be reliably applied to RNA sequencing data, thereby enhancing the utility of the genefu package across different data platforms.

6. **Unified Framework for Analysis**: The genefu package provides a unified framework for integrating molecular subtype classification and survival analysis, enabling researchers to conduct meta-analyses and integrated analyses of breast cancer gene expression profiles.

Overall, the findings highlight the importance of computational tools like genefu in advancing the understanding and treatment of breast cancer through improved molecular classification and prognostic assessment.

qa_pairs.question: Can you provide a summary of the literature review from the paper?
qa_pairs.answer:
The literature review in the paper "Gene expression Genefu: an R/Bioconductor package for computation of gene expression-based signatures in breast cancer" provides a comprehensive overview of the advancements in understanding the molecular heterogeneity of breast cancer. It highlights the following key points:

1. **Molecular Subtypes**: Breast cancer is characterized by at least four clinically relevant molecular subtypes—Her2-enriched, Triple-negative, and Luminal-like (further divided into Luminal A and B). These subtypes exhibit distinct gene expression patterns that correlate with patient outcomes, underscoring the complexity of breast cancer as a heterogeneous disease.

2. **Gene Expression Profiling**: The review emphasizes the increasing use of gene expression profiling to refine breast cancer stratification and assess prognosis and treatment responses. Numerous prognostic predictors and subtype-specific signatures have been developed, although the variability in reported signatures complicates comparisons across studies.

3. **Meta-Analyses**: Multiple meta-analyses have shown that many prognostic signatures perform similarly despite having limited overlap in the genes they include. However, most of these signatures have been primarily validated in luminal-like breast tumors, indicating a need for subtype-specific prognostic models.

4. **Computational Complexity**: The rapid development of classification algorithms and molecular subtyping methods has created a burden of computational complexity for researchers, necessitating accessible platforms for analysis and comparison of these diverse approaches.

5. **Integration of High-Throughput Data**: The literature review discusses the potential of high-throughput genomics and next-generation sequencing to provide deeper insights into breast cancer subtypes, while also highlighting the need for computational tools that can handle the growing variety of classification and prognostic algorithms.

6. **Development of Genefu**: In response to these challenges, the authors present the genefu package, which integrates various bioinformatics algorithms and gene signatures for molecular subtyping and prognostication in breast cancer. This package aims to facilitate meta-analyses and comparisons across different datasets and algorithms.

Overall, the literature review underscores the importance of molecular subtyping in breast cancer research and the need for robust computational tools to support ongoing investigations in this complex field.

qa_pairs.question: What future research directions do the authors suggest in the paper?
qa_pairs.answer:
The authors suggest several future research directions in the paper. They highlight the need for:

1. **Development of Subtype-Specific Prognostic Models**: The authors emphasize that the prognostic value of existing signatures is largely limited to luminal-like breast tumors. They call for the creation of more subtype-specific prognostic models to enhance the accuracy of predictions for other subtypes, particularly basal-like and HER2-enriched tumors.

2. **Integration of New Molecular Subtyping Methods**: The paper indicates that the parallel development of breast cancer subtyping methods has resulted in a variety of classification algorithms. Future research should focus on integrating these new methods into existing frameworks to improve the understanding of breast cancer heterogeneity.

3. **Cross-Comparison of Computational Methods**: The authors point out the computational complexity introduced by the vast literature on breast cancer. They advocate for accessible computational platforms that can facilitate the comparison of different classification and prognostic algorithms, which would aid in meta-analyses and integrated analyses of breast cancer data.

4. **Evaluation of RNA Sequencing Data**: The authors mention the importance of assessing whether molecular subtyping algorithms and gene expression signatures derived from microarray data can be reliably applied to RNA sequencing data. Future studies should continue to explore this area to ensure that methodologies remain relevant as technology evolves.

Overall, the authors stress the importance of refining prognostic models, integrating new algorithms, and ensuring compatibility with emerging data technologies to advance breast cancer research.

qa_pairs.question: What statistical techniques were used in the paper?
qa_pairs.answer:
The paper describes the use of several statistical techniques in the context of gene expression analysis and breast cancer prognostication. The key statistical techniques mentioned include:

1. **Concordance Index**: This is used to measure the performance of risk prediction models. It estimates the probability that, for a random pair of patients, the patient with an earlier recurrence has a higher risk score than the patient with either later or no recurrence.

2. **Random-Effects Model**: This model is employed to combine dataset-specific performance estimates into an overall performance estimate for each risk prediction model.

3. **Gaussian-Based Clustering**: This technique is utilized for identifying breast cancer molecular subtypes based on gene sets correlated with specific genes (e.g., ER, HER2, AURKA).

4. **Meta-Analysis**: The paper discusses conducting meta-analyses of prognostic signatures across multiple breast cancer datasets, which involves statistical methods to combine results from different studies.

5. **Kaplan-Meier Curves**: These curves are used to visualize survival probabilities across different molecular subtypes, providing a statistical method for estimating survival functions.

These techniques collectively facilitate the analysis of gene expression data, the comparison of different prognostic models, and the evaluation of their performance across various datasets.

qa_pairs.question: What are the implications of the research findings?
qa_pairs.answer:
The implications of the research findings presented in the paper on the genefu R/Bioconductor package for breast cancer gene expression analysis are multifaceted:

1. **Enhanced Prognostication**: The development of the genefu package allows for improved prognostic predictions across various breast cancer subtypes. By integrating multiple prognostic predictors and gene signatures, it facilitates more accurate risk assessments for patients, particularly for those with luminal-like tumors, which have previously been the focus of many prognostic models.

2. **Facilitation of Meta-Analyses**: The package provides a unified framework for conducting meta-analyses across different datasets and algorithms. This capability is crucial for researchers aiming to compare and validate existing gene expression signatures and classification models, thereby enhancing the reliability of findings in breast cancer research.

3. **Support for Molecular Subtyping**: The inclusion of various molecular subtyping algorithms within genefu aids in the identification of breast cancer subtypes, which is essential for personalized treatment approaches. The ability to compare predictions from different algorithms (e.g., PAM50 and SCMOD2) demonstrates the consistency and reliability of subtype classifications, which can guide therapeutic decisions.

4. **Accessibility of Computational Tools**: By making the genefu package available on Bioconductor and GitHub, the authors have increased accessibility to advanced bioinformatics tools for researchers and clinicians. This democratization of technology can accelerate research and clinical applications in breast cancer management.

5. **Integration of High-Throughput Data**: The findings suggest that gene expression signatures derived from microarray data can be effectively applied to RNA sequencing data. This adaptability is significant given the shift towards next-generation sequencing technologies in clinical settings, ensuring that existing knowledge can be leveraged in modern research.

6. **Identification of Molecular Complexity**: The research highlights the molecular heterogeneity of breast cancer and the need for subtype-specific prognostic models. This understanding can lead to more tailored therapeutic strategies and better patient outcomes, as treatments can be aligned with the specific molecular characteristics of a patient's tumor.

7. **Future Research Directions**: The findings underscore the need for ongoing development of computational tools and models that can keep pace with the evolving landscape of breast cancer research. The genefu package sets a precedent for future bioinformatics initiatives aimed at improving cancer classification and prognostication.

In summary, the implications of the research findings emphasize the importance of computational tools in enhancing the understanding and management of breast cancer, ultimately contributing to more personalized and effective treatment strategies.

qa_pairs.question: Can you explain the technical terms used in the paper?
qa_pairs.answer:
Certainly! Here are explanations of some of the technical terms used in the paper:

1. **Gene Expression**: This refers to the process by which information from a gene is used to synthesize a functional gene product, typically proteins. The level of gene expression can vary and is often measured to understand cellular functions and disease states.

2. **Bioconductor**: An open-source software project that provides tools for the analysis and comprehension of high-throughput genomic data. It is primarily used with the R programming language.

3. **Molecular Subtyping**: This is the classification of cancer into different subtypes based on molecular characteristics, such as gene expression patterns. In breast cancer, this helps in understanding the disease's heterogeneity and tailoring treatment strategies.

4. **Prognostic Predictors**: These are models or algorithms that predict the likely outcome of a disease, such as the risk of recurrence or survival rates, based on specific biological markers or gene expression profiles.

5. **High-Throughput Genomics**: A set of technologies that allow for the rapid sequencing and analysis of large amounts of genetic material. This enables comprehensive studies of genetic variations and expressions in cancer.

6. **Next-Generation Sequencing (NGS)**: A modern DNA sequencing technology that allows for the sequencing of entire genomes quickly and cost-effectively, providing insights into genetic variations associated with diseases.

7. **Concordance Index**: A statistical measure used to evaluate the predictive accuracy of a risk prediction model. It estimates the probability that, for a randomly selected pair of patients, the patient with the higher risk score will experience an event (like recurrence) first.

8. **Fuzzy Computational Approach**: A method that incorporates uncertainty and imprecision in data analysis, allowing for more flexible modeling of complex biological systems, such as cancer prognosis.

9. **Gene Expression Profiling**: The measurement of the activity (expression) of thousands of genes at once to create a global picture of cellular function. This is often used to identify specific gene signatures associated with different cancer types.

10. **Microarray Platforms**: Technologies used to measure the expression levels of many genes simultaneously or to genotype multiple regions of a genome. They are often used in gene expression profiling studies.

11. **RNA Sequencing (RNA-seq)**: A technique that allows for the comprehensive analysis of the transcriptome, the complete set of RNA transcripts produced by the genome under specific circumstances or in a specific cell.

12. **Claudin-low Subtype**: A specific subtype of breast cancer characterized by low expression of claudin proteins, which are involved in cell adhesion. This subtype is often associated with aggressive disease and poor prognosis.

13. **IntClust**: A molecular subtyping algorithm that classifies breast cancer into intrinsic subtypes based on gene expression data.

14. **IHC4**: An immunohistochemical scoring system used to predict the risk of recurrence in breast cancer patients based on the expression of four proteins.

15. **EndoPredict**: A prognostic test that combines clinical and molecular information to predict the risk of distant recurrence in hormone receptor-positive breast cancer patients.

These terms are integral to understanding the methodologies and findings presented in the research paper on the genefu package for breast cancer gene expression analysis.
